For more information on hurricane season preparedness visit http://www.fema.gov/disaster/4339/hurricane-preparedness.

‚Ä¢ Download the FEMA app to receive weather alerts.

Now is the time to be prepared!  If you or someone in your family is experiencing issues with disaster-related stress, call L√≠nea PAS at 800-981-0023, TTY 888-672-7622.

STAY INFORMED: Listen for up-to-date information 
‚Ä¢ Local media will provide evacuation and shelters details.
‚Ä¢ Make sure your battery-powered radio is working and you have extra batteries.

‚Ä¢ Save a few dollars each week and spread out your shopping for your 10 days‚Äô worth of supplies.
‚Ä¢ Switch your Social Security or other regular benefits to electronic payments that are deposited directly into your account.

‚Ä¢ Whether you‚Äôre a homeowner or renter, contact your insurance agent to ensure you‚Äôre adequately covered for housing, car and flooding.
‚Ä¢ Keep some cash in hand, in large and small bills.

‚Ä¢ In mass care shelters, pets will be taken to a reserved space. Certified service pets are allowed to stay with their owners for emotional support.

BE FINANCIALLY PREPARED: Consider the costs associated with disasters
‚Ä¢ Anticipate out-of-pocket expenses for lodging, food, gas

PROTECT YOUR PETS: Make sure someone is available to care of your pets if you can‚Äôt
‚Ä¢ Get food, water and a collar with identification tag.
‚Ä¢ Keep pets inside the house or take them to a pre-identified safe location.

‚Ä¢ If relying on public transportation, contact your local emergency agencies about evacuation procedures.
‚Ä¢ If you plan to stay at home, make sure it is in good repair and have the plywood, steel or aluminum panels to board up windows and doors.

‚Ä¢ Keep important phone numbers with you at all times.

ASSESS YOUR SHELTERING NEEDS: Identify where you will shelter 
‚Ä¢ Identify where you will shelter in case you are ordered to leave your home, and share the location with your family.

MAKE A FAMILY PLAN: Identify alternate ways to stay in touch with loved ones 
‚Ä¢ Choose an out of town friend or relative as a point of contact.
‚Ä¢ Decide on a meeting place in case you cannot return home.

BUILD A KIT: Be sure you have at least 10 days of supplies
‚Ä¢ Store a gallon of water, food, prescriptions and other supplies per person per day. Pay special attention to infants, the elderly and people with disabilities and access and functional needs.
